questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment-producing, velvety colonies with characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it the causative agent of various dermatophyte infections including tinea corporis that could present with itching in the axilla. Understanding the colony morphology and microscopic features is crucial for accurate identification and appropriate treatment of dermatophyte infections.

questions.text: Which among the following occupation is a risk factor for this presenting illness? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kennel worker

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cutaneous larva migrans, caused by nematode larvae from Ancylostoma species, is commonly associated with occupations that involve close contact with contaminated soil and animal feces, such as kennel workers.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to have endemic transmission in India? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has been reported to have endemic transmission in India, specifically with an outbreak in Gujarat in 2011.

questions.text: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for diagnosis of which of the following condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Toxoplasmosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Sabin-Feldman dye test remains a gold standard for the serological diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis due to its ability to detect the presence of specific antibodies against Toxoplasma gondii, reflecting the body's immune response to the infection.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Skin test for diagnosis of parasitic infections:
  • ➤ Casoni test – Hydatid disease Montenegro test – Kala azar Frenkel test – Toxoplasmosis Fairley test – Schistosomiasis Bachman test – Trichinellosis
  • ➤ Casoni test – Hydatid disease
  • ➤ Casoni test
  • ➤ Montenegro test – Kala azar
  • ➤ Montenegro test
  • ➤ Frenkel test – Toxoplasmosis
  • ➤ Fairley test – Schistosomiasis
  • ➤ Bachman test – Trichinellosis

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He had a history of contact with multiple sexual partners. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. The fungal culture of sputum was negative. On Gomori methamine silver staining, the cells showed darkly stained crescent-shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pneumocystis jerovecii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a critical opportunistic infection in HIV/AIDS patients, characterized by non-specific respiratory symptoms and distinctive cystic structures on Gomori methenamine silver staining. Regular prophylaxis and monitoring are essential for at-risk populations.

questions.text: Which virus requires reverse transcriptase PCR for detection? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) RSV

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is an RNA virus that requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) to convert its RNA into DNA for detection. RT-PCR is a sensitive method used to detect and quantify RNA viruses by first converting their RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using the enzyme reverse transcriptase.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses are DNA viruses and do not require reverse transcription. They can be detected using standard PCR methods that amplify their DNA directly.
  • • Option B. Herpes virus:
  • • Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): Epstein-Barr Virus is a DNA virus and uses standard PCR for detection. Reverse transcription is not necessary for DNA viruses.
  • • Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus):
  • • Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Cytomegalovirus is also a DNA virus and can be detected through standard DNA PCR. Reverse transcription is not needed for its detection.
  • • Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ RSV, an RNA virus, requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) for detection by converting RNA into DNA.

questions.text: A patient presented with case of diarrhea after eating sea food/ oyster, showing Kanagawa phenomenon. What is the causative organism? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vibrio parahemolyticus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Vibrio parahemolyticus causes Food-borne gastroenteritis
  • • MC presentation Following uncooked sea food (e.g. Oyster and shellfish) intake. Watery diarrhea (MC), dysentery, abdominal cramps. Extraintestinal manifestations → wound infection, otitis and sepsis.
  • • MC presentation
  • • Following uncooked sea food (e.g. Oyster and shellfish) intake.
  • • Watery diarrhea (MC), dysentery, abdominal cramps.
  • • Extraintestinal manifestations → wound infection, otitis and sepsis.
  • • Bipolar staining – safety pin appearance is seen in 5 bacteria’s –
  • • Bipolar staining – safety pin appearance is seen in 5 bacteria’s –
  • • Mnemonic
  • • Mnemonic
  • • Note - Kanagawa phenomenon
  • • Note - Kanagawa phenomenon
  • • V. parahaemolyticus produce Beta hemolysis on special blood agar medium → called the Wagatsuma agar Wagatsuma agar → High-salt (7%) blood agar (defibrinated human or rabbit blood) medium containing d-mannitol as the carbohydrate source. Hemolysis observed on Wagatsuma agar medium, referred to as the Kanagawa phenomenon (KP).
  • • V. parahaemolyticus produce Beta hemolysis on special blood agar medium → called the Wagatsuma agar
  • • Wagatsuma agar → High-salt (7%) blood agar (defibrinated human or rabbit blood) medium containing d-mannitol as the carbohydrate source.
  • • Hemolysis observed on Wagatsuma agar medium, referred to as the Kanagawa phenomenon (KP).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vibrio cholera: Causes cholera, characterized by severe watery diarrhea but not typically associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.
  • • Option A. Vibrio cholera:
  • • Option C. E. coli: Can cause gastroenteritis but is not associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.
  • • Option C. E. coli:
  • • Option D. Vibrio vulnificus: Can cause severe infections from seafood consumption but is not typically associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.
  • • Option D. Vibrio vulnificus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vibrio parahemolyticus is the causative organism of gastroenteritis following the consumption of uncooked seafood, identified by the Kanagawa phenomenon. The most common symptoms are watery diarrhea, dysentery, and abdominal cramps.
  • ➤ Additional Information -
  • ➤ Additional Information -
  • ➤ Classification based on Salt Requirement
  • ➤ 1. Nonhalophilic vibrios:
  • ➤ Can grow without salt but 1% salt is optimum for their growth. Cannot grow at higher salt concentrations. Examples → V. cholerae and V. mimicus
  • ➤ Can grow without salt but 1% salt is optimum for their growth.
  • ➤ Cannot grow at higher salt concentrations.
  • ➤ Examples → V. cholerae and V. mimicus
  • ➤ 2. Halophilic vibrios:
  • ➤ Cannot grow in the absence of salt. Can tolerate and grow at higher salt concentration of up to 7–10%. Examples → V. parahaemolyticus, V. alginolyticus and V. vulnificus.
  • ➤ Cannot grow in the absence of salt.
  • ➤ Can tolerate and grow at higher salt concentration of up to 7–10%. Examples → V. parahaemolyticus, V. alginolyticus and V. vulnificus.

questions.text: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Herpes simplex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inclusion bodies produced in viral infection:
  • ➤ Inclusion bodies produced in viral infection:

questions.text: Best method of diagnosis for Clostridium difficile? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.correct_answer: C. Toxin gene detection by PCR
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Toxin gene detection by PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best method for diagnosing Clostridium difficile infection is through nucleic acid amplification tests, such as PCR assays, which detect the toxin A or B genes in stool due to their high sensitivity, specificity, and rapid turnaround time.

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus can cause rapid-onset food poisoning characterized by nausea and vomiting, typically within hours after consuming contaminated food such as pastries. Remembering the association between specific foods and pathogens can aid in prompt diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with fatigue and tiredness. He had low Hb and reticulocyte count. BM reveals a decrease in erythroid precursors. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pure red cell aplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pure red cell aplasia is characterized by a specific decrease in erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to anemia with normal WBC and platelet counts.

questions.text: A patient has complained of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain? ( INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Toluidine and malachite green

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Albert stain contains Toluidine blue and Malachite green, used to identify metachromatic granules in bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: Which of the following are acid-fast staining organisms? (INICET MAY 2022) Nocardia Mycobacterium leprae Actinomyces Cryptosporidium parvum Isospora belli
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4, 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Isospora belli are acid-fast staining organisms.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from fever and he is diagnosed with condition caused by a lactose fermenting bacteria, he is advised for culture, Which culture media is used to differentiate lactose and non-lactose fermenter? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mac conkey agar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MacConkey agar is a selective and differential medium used to distinguish lactose fermenters, which appear as pink colonies, from non-lactose fermenters, which appear as colorless or pale colonies.

questions.text: The microorganism demonstrates resistance to meropenem and aminoglycosides, while being susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole. Which microorganism is most likely responsible? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stenotrophomonas maltophila

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stenotrophomonas maltophila is an opportunistic pathogen resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides but susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: What is the primary function of the condenser in a compound microscope? ( AIIMS May 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: To hold and support the specimen slide

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the amount of light reaching the specimen

options.label: D
options.text: To adjust the focus and clarity of the image

questions.correct_answer: C. To regulate the amount of light reaching the specimen
questions.explanation: Ans. C) To regulate the amount of light reaching the specimen

questions.text: Diarrhea, falling leaf motility, 4 pairs of flagella, tennis racket shape are seen in? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite that causes gastrointestinal illness, typically presenting with diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and malabsorption. The characteristic "falling leaf" motility and the presence of four pairs of flagella (eight flagella in total) are key diagnostic features.
  • • The characteristic "falling leaf" motility and the presence of four pairs of flagella (eight flagella in total) are key diagnostic features.
  • • Giardia lamblia exists in two forms:
  • • Trophozoite: The active, motile form. It has a distinctive shape often described as a tennis racket, teardrop, or monkey face. The trophozoite has two nuclei, four pairs of flagella, and two parabasal bodies. Cyst: The infective form. It is oval-shaped with a thick wall, containing four nuclei when mature. The cyst form is responsible for transmission through contaminated water or food.
  • • Trophozoite: The active, motile form. It has a distinctive shape often described as a tennis racket, teardrop, or monkey face. The trophozoite has two nuclei, four pairs of flagella, and two parabasal bodies.
  • • Trophozoite:
  • • Cyst: The infective form. It is oval-shaped with a thick wall, containing four nuclei when mature. The cyst form is responsible for transmission through contaminated water or food.
  • • Cyst:
  • • The images provided show the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia with its characteristic features, including the flagella and the distinctive shape.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Listeria: Listeria is a bacterium, not a protozoan. It does not exhibit the described features of falling leaf motility or multiple flagella.
  • • Option B. Listeria:
  • • Option C. Trichomonas: Trichomonas is a flagellated protozoan but does not have the same morphological characteristics as Giardia lamblia. It typically affects the urogenital tract rather than causing diarrhea.
  • • Option C. Trichomonas:
  • • Option D. Balantidium coli: This is a ciliated protozoan that causes dysentery, not typically associated with the described motility or flagella characteristics of Giardia.
  • • Option D. Balantidium coli:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giardia lamblia is identified by its unique "falling leaf" motility, presence of four pairs of flagella, and its characteristic tennis racket or teardrop shape in its trophozoite form. It is a common cause of diarrhea and gastrointestinal discomfort.
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Classification:
  • ➤ Classification:
  • ➤ Life cycle
  • ➤ Life cycle
  • ➤ Malabsorption syndrome
  • ➤ Malabsorption syndrome
  • ➤ Abdominal pain , Nausea and vomiting Malabsorption of fat (steatorrhea) → leads to foul smelling profuse frothy diarrhea Malabsorption of Disaccharidase (lactose, xylose) → leading to lactose intolerance Malabsorption of vitamin A, B12 and iron Protein loosing enteropathy.
  • ➤ Abdominal pain , Nausea and vomiting
  • ➤ Malabsorption of fat (steatorrhea) → leads to foul smelling profuse frothy diarrhea
  • ➤ Malabsorption of Disaccharidase (lactose, xylose) → leading to lactose intolerance
  • ➤ Malabsorption of vitamin A, B12 and iron
  • ➤ Protein loosing enteropathy.

questions.text: A person who has undergone a bone marrow transplant in the past is now presenting with a lung lesion. Upon microscopic analysis, the image of the lesion is provided below. What is the probable responsible organism for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Mucormycosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mucormycosis is indicated in this clinical scenario due to the patient's history of a bone marrow transplant and the presence of a lung lesion. The image provided shows broad aseptate hyphae , which is characteristic of Mucormycosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Histoplasma: Is a dimorphic fungus. At 25°C, it shows mycelial phase and at 37°C, it shows Yeast form.
  • • Option A.
  • • Histoplasma:
  • • Option B. Cryptococcus: Colonies can be demonstrated by negative staining of their capsule.
  • • Option B.
  • • Cryptococcus:
  • • Option D . Aspergillosis: Shows narrow, acute angled branching and septate, differing from the non-septate hyphae
  • • Option D
  • • Aspergillosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucormycosis is characterized broad aseptate hyphae with acute -angle branching. which commonly affecting in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Identify the following? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Giardia lamblia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giardia lamblia in its cyst form, is the infective stage responsible for transmission through contaminated water, food, or fecal-oral route.

questions.text: A PLHIV with low CD4 count admitted with pneumonia. GMS stain of BAL shown in the image. Choose the correct agent: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumocystis jirovecii is a common cause of pneumonia in HIV patients with low CD4 counts and is identified by its characteristic crushed ping-pong ball appearance in GMS-stained samples.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe pneumonia following influenza infection. Culture shows gram-positive cocci growing as alpha-hemolytic colonies on blood agar, optochin sensitive. Identify the organism: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pneumoniae

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The characteristics described are typical of Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus): gram-positive cocci in chains, alpha-hemolytic colonies on blood agar, and optochin sensitivity. This organism commonly causes secondary bacterial pneumonia following viral respiratory infections, particularly influenza.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Haemophilus influenzae: Gram-negative coccobacillus requiring X and V factors, grows on chocolate agar, not blood agar.
  • • Option A. Haemophilus influenzae:
  • • Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Gram-positive cocci in clusters, produces beta-hemolysis, and is coagulase-positive. Not sensitive to optochin.
  • • Option C. Staphylococcus aureus:
  • • Option D. Moraxella catarrhalis: Gram-negative diplococci, oxidase-positive, grows on blood agar but doesn't show hemolysis.
  • • Option D. Moraxella catarrhalis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand key diagnostic features of respiratory pathogens:
  • ➤ S. pneumoniae: Alpha-hemolysis, optochin sensitivity Colony morphology and biochemical tests essential for identification Post-viral bacterial pneumonia often caused by specific pathogens
  • ➤ S. pneumoniae: Alpha-hemolysis, optochin sensitivity
  • ➤ Colony morphology and biochemical tests essential for identification
  • ➤ Post-viral bacterial pneumonia often caused by specific pathogens
  • ➤ Importance of distinguishing between different respiratory bacteria

questions.text: Weil’s disease is caused by: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leptospira Interrogans

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Weil’s disease refers to a severe form of leptospirosis caused by Leptospira interrogans. Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. It presents with various clinical findings including fever, jaundice, renal failure, hemorrhage, and refractory shock. The disease is primarily transmitted through contact with water or soil contaminated with the urine of infected animals, especially rodents.
  • • Leptospirosis Overview:
  • • Leptospirosis Overview:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Borrelia Recurrentis: Causes relapsing fever.
  • • Option B. Borrelia Recurrentis:
  • • Option C. Treponema Endemicum: Causes bejel.
  • • Option
  • • C. Treponema Endemicum:
  • • Option D. Borrelia Burgdorferi: Causes Lyme disease.
  • • Option
  • • D. Borrelia Burgdorferi:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Weil’s disease, a severe form of leptospirosis, is caused by Leptospira interrogans and involves symptoms such as jaundice, renal failure, and hemorrhage.

questions.text: The following image depicts: ( INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Production of monoclonal antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The process depicted in the images is the production of monoclonal antibodies using hybridoma technology.

questions.text: A patient presents with productive cough for 3 months, evening rise of temperature, and significant weight loss. A sputum examination is ordered for AFB. What are the constituents of the primary stain used in this test? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.correct_answer: B. Basic fuchsin and phenol (Carbol fuchsin)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Basic fuchsin and phenol (Carbol fuchsin)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The classical Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining for acid-fast bacilli uses carbol fuchsin as the primary stain, which is composed of basic fuchsin and phenol. The phenol enhances the penetration of the dye into the mycolic acid-rich cell wall of mycobacteria, while basic fuchsin provides the red color that resists decolorization with acid-alcohol.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Toluidine blue and malachite green: These are components of Albert's stain used for identifying metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • • Option A. Toluidine blue and malachite green:
  • • Option C. Crystal violet and safranin: These are components of Gram staining, with crystal violet as primary stain and safranin as counterstain.
  • • Option C. Crystal violet and safranin:
  • • Option D. Methylene blue and iodine: These are components used in different staining techniques but not together as primary stain for AFB.
  • • Option D. Methylene blue and iodine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the composition and principles of different bacterial staining methods:
  • ➤ ZN stain: Carbol fuchsin (primary), acid-alcohol (decolorizer), methylene blue (counterstain) Purpose: To identify acid-fast organisms like Mycobacterium tuberculosis Principle: Mycolic acid in cell wall retains primary stain despite acid-alcohol treatment
  • ➤ ZN stain: Carbol fuchsin (primary), acid-alcohol (decolorizer), methylene blue (counterstain)
  • ➤ Purpose: To identify acid-fast organisms like Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • ➤ Principle: Mycolic acid in cell wall retains primary stain despite acid-alcohol treatment

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with fever, headache, and a characteristic skin lesion as shown in the image, 5 days after a camping trip in the Rocky Mountains. The rash started on his ankles and wrists, later spreading to his trunk. Which is the most likely diagnosis? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rocky Mountain spotted fever

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows a characteristic maculopapular rash of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), caused by Rickettsia rickettsii and transmitted by Dermacentor ticks.
  • • Key features of RMSF include:
  • • Rash appears 2-4 days after fever onset Begins as small, flat, pink macules on wrists, forearms, and ankles Centripetal spread (periphery to trunk) May involve palms and soles Associated with severe headache and fever Treatment: Doxycycline
  • • Rash appears 2-4 days after fever onset
  • • Begins as small, flat, pink macules on wrists, forearms, and ankles
  • • Centripetal spread (periphery to trunk)
  • • May involve palms and soles
  • • Associated with severe headache and fever
  • • Treatment: Doxycycline
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Scrub typhus: Incorrect. Caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, characterized by an eschar (black, necrotic ulcer with surrounding erythema) at the site of chigger bite, not a diffuse rash.
  • • Option A. Scrub typhus: Incorrect.
  • • Option C. COVID-19: Incorrect. Various cutaneous manifestations may occur but typically presents with respiratory symptoms. The rash pattern is not characteristic of COVID-19.
  • • Option C. COVID-19: Incorrect.
  • • Option D. Lyme disease: Incorrect. Presents with erythema migrans - a bull's eye lesion that appears at the tick bite site, different from the diffuse rash of RMSF.
  • • Option D. Lyme disease: Incorrect.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To differentiate between tick-borne illnesses based on characteristic rash patterns - RMSF shows a centripetal spreading maculopapular rash, while scrub typhus shows an eschar, and Lyme disease shows erythema migrans.

questions.text: A female patient who is from the north-eastern part of the country came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. On examination, the limbs are more swollen proximally than distally. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.correct_answer: B. Night blood test for worms
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Night blood test for worms

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In regions endemic for filariasis, such as parts of northeastern India, the presentation of unexplained lymphedema warrants a night blood test for worms to check for the presence of microfilariae. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent the progression of lymphatic damage and reduce the severity of lymphedema.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognizing the distinctive egg morphology of Trichuris trichiura in stool samples is crucial for diagnosing whipworm infection. Proper sanitation and hygiene are key in preventing soil-transmitted helminth infections, and treatment involves specific antihelminthic medications to reduce the worm burden and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: The following are parvovirus-related manifestations. Identify the incorrect pair? (Twisted PYQ) Pure red cell aplasia - immunocompetent adults Papular-purpuric gloves and socks syndrome - younger adults Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women Erythema infectiosum - children
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand that parvovirus B19 manifestations vary by host factors:
  • ➤ Pure red cell aplasia occurs in immunocompromised hosts PPGSS affects young adults Hydrops fetalis is a risk in pregnancy Erythema infectiosum is common in children
  • ➤ Pure red cell aplasia occurs in immunocompromised hosts
  • ➤ PPGSS affects young adults
  • ➤ Hydrops fetalis is a risk in pregnancy
  • ➤ Erythema infectiosum is common in children

questions.text: A Cattle farmer with a scab lesion in the arm. Microscopic examination shows brick/box shaped gram-positive organism with squared ends and spores in the centre. Most likely organism which is responsible for his condition is? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bacillus anthracis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bacillus anthracis, with its brick/boxcar shape and central spores, is the causative agent of cutaneous anthrax, a zoonotic infection often seen in individuals handling livestock or animal products.

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Roseola infantum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.
  • ➤ Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the sandwich ELISA technique, the enzyme conjugate is part of the detection antibody, which binds to the antigen and, upon addition of a substrate, produces a detectable signal. In this diagram, '2' is identified as the enzyme conjugate.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, and myalgia 10 days after a camping trip. Peripheral blood smear examination reveals characteristic inclusion bodies (morulae) in neutrophils as shown in the image. Identify the most likely causative organism? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anaplasma phagocytophilum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Anaplasma phagocytophilum is an obligate intracellular bacterium that causes Human Granulocytic Anaplasmosis (HGA). The key diagnostic feature is the presence of morulae (mulberry-like inclusion bodies) in neutrophils, as opposed to monocytes.
  • • Characteristics and Clinical Presentation:
  • • Characteristics and Clinical Presentation:
  • • Transmission: Through Ixodes scapularis (deer tick) Symptoms: Fever, headache, myalgia, malaise, and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms occurring 1-2 weeks after tick exposure Diagnosis: Visualization of morulae in neutrophils on blood smear, PCR, and serologic testing Treatment: Doxycycline is the drug of choice
  • • Transmission: Through Ixodes scapularis (deer tick)
  • • Transmission:
  • • Symptoms: Fever, headache, myalgia, malaise, and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms occurring 1-2 weeks after tick exposure
  • • Symptoms:
  • • Diagnosis: Visualization of morulae in neutrophils on blood smear, PCR, and serologic testing
  • • Diagnosis:
  • • Treatment: Doxycycline is the drug of choice
  • • Treatment:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: Incorrect. While it also causes similar symptoms, E. chaffeensis forms morulae in monocytes, not neutrophils.
  • • Option A. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: Incorrect.
  • • Option C. Rickettsia rickettsii: Incorrect. Causes Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever and does not form morulae in any white blood cells.
  • • Option C. Rickettsia rickettsii: Incorrect.
  • • Option D. Rickettsia conorii: Incorrect. Causes Mediterranean Spotted Fever and also does not form characteristic morulae.
  • • Option D. Rickettsia conorii: Incorrect.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To differentiate between Anaplasma and Ehrlichia based on their characteristic cell tropism - Anaplasma forms morulae in granulocytes (neutrophils) while Ehrlichia forms them in monocytes. Both are tick-borne illnesses treated with doxycycline.
  • ➤ GAME - Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis
  • ➤ GAME - Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with multiple abscesses over his face, chest, and back. The child has a history of recurrent respiratory infections. On examination, he has atopic excoriating skin and multiple cold abscesses on his back. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyper IgE syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyper IgE syndrome should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of high IgE levels, recurrent skin and respiratory infections, and dermatologic issues such as eczema. Managing this condition often involves addressing the skin care comprehensively and preventing infections through vigilant monitoring and appropriate use of antibiotics.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enveloped ss RNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles virus is characterized as an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus, notable for the unique clinical presentation of Koplik's spots, which precede the characteristic maculopapular rash. This distinguishing feature is essential for the clinical diagnosis of measles.

questions.text: A patient with crushed limb after amputation developed crepitus. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gas gangrene

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient had a crushed limb that required amputation. After the amputation, the patient developed crepitus, which refers to the presence of gas bubbles in the tissues. The development of crepitus after an injury or amputation suggests a gas-forming bacterial infection, specifically gas gangrene. Gas gangrene is caused by the bacteria Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens, which can contaminate wounds from soil or other environmental sources. Clostridium perfringens is a gas-forming bacteria that ferments sugars (such as glucose in the body) into acid and gas, leading to tissue necrosis and the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the gangrenous tissue.
  • • The patient had a crushed limb that required amputation.
  • • After the amputation, the patient developed crepitus, which refers to the presence of gas bubbles in the tissues.
  • • The development of crepitus after an injury or amputation suggests a gas-forming bacterial infection, specifically gas gangrene.
  • • Gas gangrene is caused by the bacteria Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens, which can contaminate wounds from soil or other environmental sources.
  • • Clostridium perfringens is a gas-forming bacteria that ferments sugars (such as glucose in the body) into acid and gas, leading to tissue necrosis and the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the gangrenous tissue.
  • • The presence of crepitus, along with the history of a crushed limb and amputation, strongly suggests gas gangrene as the diagnosis.
  • • Established agents:
  • • Established agents:
  • • C. perfringens C. novyi C. septicum
  • • C. perfringens
  • • C. novyi
  • • C. septicum
  • • Probable agents: C. histolyticum, C. sporogenes, C. fallax, C. bifermentans, C. sordellii, C. aerofoetidum, and C. tertium.
  • • Probable agents:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cellulitis: This is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth, but it does not typically involve the formation of gas bubbles.
  • • Option A. Cellulitis:
  • • Option B. Necrotizing fasciitis: This is a severe bacterial infection of the fascia (connective tissue) that can lead to tissue necrosis, but it is not specifically associated with the formation of gas bubbles.
  • • Option B. Necrotizing fasciitis:
  • • Option C. Folliculitis: This is an infection of the hair follicles, which is unlikely to occur after an amputation and does not involve gas formation.
  • • Option C. Folliculitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gas gangrene is a potentially life-threatening infection caused by gas-forming Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens. It is characterized by the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the necrotic and gangrenous tissues, typically occurring after traumatic injuries or surgical procedures that allow the contamination of wounds with soil or environmental sources.

questions.text: Patient came with fever, rash and eschar formation. On examination, mite bite was also present. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Scrub typhus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The key points that support this diagnosis are:
  • • The key points that support this diagnosis are:
  • • The presence of eschar , which is a common finding in scrub typhus and anthrax. The mite bite , which is the biggest clue provided, as scrub typhus is transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers). The explanation that among the rickettsial diseases mentioned in the options (scrub typhus, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and epidemic typhus), only scrub typhus is transmitted by mites.
  • • The presence of eschar , which is a common finding in scrub typhus and anthrax.
  • • eschar
  • • The mite bite , which is the biggest clue provided, as scrub typhus is transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers).
  • • mite bite
  • • The explanation that among the rickettsial diseases mentioned in the options (scrub typhus, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and epidemic typhus), only scrub typhus is transmitted by mites.
  • • Scrub typhus is a rickettsial disease caused by the bacteria Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by the bite of larval mites, commonly known as chiggers.
  • • Triad – Eschar; Regional lymphadenopathy and Maculopapular rash
  • • *Coxiella and Bartonella are now excluded from this family
  • • *Coxiella and Bartonella are now excluded from this family
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anthrax: Anthrax is caused by the bacteria Bacillus anthracis and is not transmitted by mite bites. It is a zoonotic disease acquired through contact with infected animals or their products, inhalation of spores, or ingestion of contaminated food.
  • • Option A. Anthrax:
  • • Option C. Rocky Mountain spotted fever: This is another rickettsial disease, but it is transmitted by ticks, not mites. The presence of a mite bite in the given scenario rules out this option.
  • • Option C. Rocky Mountain spotted fever:
  • • Option D. Epidemic Typhus: Caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and transmitted by lice, epidemic typhus presents with a rash but does not typically include eschar formation, nor is it associated with mite bites.
  • • Option D. Epidemic Typhus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scrub typhus is a rickettsial disease caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers). The presence of eschar, fever, rash, and a mite bite are key clinical features suggestive of this diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is called as Australia antigen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) HBsAg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HBsAg, also known as the Australia antigen, plays a pivotal role in the diagnosis and monitoring of Hepatitis B infection. Its presence in the blood typically indicates an active Hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: Urine LAM is used for the diagnosis of? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) M. tuberculosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urine LAM assay is a diagnostic tool for tuberculosis, particularly useful for patients with HIV and low CD4 counts due to the detection of the LAM antigen from mycobacterial cell walls in urine.
  • ➤ Urine LAM assay is a diagnostic tool for tuberculosis, particularly useful for patients with HIV and low CD4 counts due to the detection of the LAM antigen from mycobacterial cell walls in urine.

questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of thick white vaginal secretions. Which of the following can be used to identify the likely species of the causative agent? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CHROMagar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CHROMagar is the preferred medium for rapidly identifying and differentiating various Candida species directly from clinical specimens like vaginal swabs, with Candida albicans typically forming green colonies on this medium. This tool is essential for quick, accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment of candidiasis.

questions.text: Parthenogenesis is seen in which of the following worm? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

Explanation:

  • • Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the nematodes because it can reproduce through parthenogenesis. This means that the female worms can produce fertile eggs without mating with a male. In the human host, only female Strongyloides worms are found in the intestine, and they are capable of producing eggs or larvae without male fertilization. Oviparous, Viviparous, and Oviviparous Nematodes: Oviparous: These worms lay eggs which then develop outside the female’s body. Examples include Ascaris and Trichuris. Viviparous: These worms give birth to live larvae. Examples include some species of Dracunculus and Wuchereria. Oviviparous: These worms lay eggs that hatch immediately as they are laid, producing larvae. Strongyloides stercoralis is an example, as the eggs hatch into larvae almost immediately after being laid.
  • • Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the nematodes because it can reproduce through parthenogenesis. This means that the female worms can produce fertile eggs without mating with a male. In the human host, only female Strongyloides worms are found in the intestine, and they are capable of producing eggs or larvae without male fertilization.
  • • Strongyloides stercoralis:
  • • Oviparous, Viviparous, and Oviviparous Nematodes: Oviparous: These worms lay eggs which then develop outside the female’s body. Examples include Ascaris and Trichuris. Viviparous: These worms give birth to live larvae. Examples include some species of Dracunculus and Wuchereria. Oviviparous: These worms lay eggs that hatch immediately as they are laid, producing larvae. Strongyloides stercoralis is an example, as the eggs hatch into larvae almost immediately after being laid.
  • • Oviparous, Viviparous, and Oviviparous Nematodes:
  • • Oviparous: These worms lay eggs which then develop outside the female’s body. Examples include Ascaris and Trichuris. Viviparous: These worms give birth to live larvae. Examples include some species of Dracunculus and Wuchereria. Oviviparous: These worms lay eggs that hatch immediately as they are laid, producing larvae. Strongyloides stercoralis is an example, as the eggs hatch into larvae almost immediately after being laid.
  • • Oviparous: These worms lay eggs which then develop outside the female’s body. Examples include Ascaris and Trichuris.
  • • Oviparous:
  • • Viviparous: These worms give birth to live larvae. Examples include some species of Dracunculus and Wuchereria.
  • • Viviparous:
  • • Oviviparous: These worms lay eggs that hatch immediately as they are laid, producing larvae. Strongyloides stercoralis is an example, as the eggs hatch into larvae almost immediately after being laid.
  • • Oviviparous:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Trichuris trichura: This worm is oviparous, meaning it lays eggs that develop and hatch outside the female’s body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.
  • • Option A. Trichuris trichura:
  • • Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is also an oviparous worm. It lays eggs that develop in the external environment.
  • • Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale:
  • • Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, it is also oviparous, laying eggs that hatch outside the body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.
  • • Option D. Enterobius vermicularis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parthenogenesis, where a female worm can produce offspring without male fertilization, is a unique reproductive strategy seen in Strongyloides stercoralis. This worm is also oviviparous, laying eggs that hatch almost immediately.

questions.text: Identify the condition that presents with painful vesicles as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Herpes simplex virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Painful vesicles are characteristic of herpes simplex virus infection. Remember the association of HSV with painful, fluid-filled vesicles, especially in genital or mucosal areas.

questions.text: A patient was injured with a rusted metal object. What is the mechanism of action of tetanus toxin in such cases? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Inhibit the release of GABA and glycine

questions.correct_answer: A. Inhibit the release of GABA and glycine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inhibit the release of GABA and glycine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetanus toxin (tetanospasmin) inhibits the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contractions and the characteristic spasms of tetanus.

questions.text: Mode of transmission of abdominal TB includes all except? ( INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Direct contact with infected animal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Modes of spread:
  • ➤ Modes of spread:
  • ➤ By ingesting Infected food or milk - Primary intestinal tuberculosis Infected sputum - Secondary intestinal tuberculosis Hematogenous spread from distant tubercular focus Contagious spread from infected adjacent foci Through lymphatic channel Common site of abdominal TB - Terminal ileum and cecum
  • ➤ By ingesting Infected food or milk - Primary intestinal tuberculosis Infected sputum - Secondary intestinal tuberculosis
  • ➤ Infected food or milk - Primary intestinal tuberculosis Infected sputum - Secondary intestinal tuberculosis
  • ➤ Infected food or milk - Primary intestinal tuberculosis
  • ➤ Infected sputum - Secondary intestinal tuberculosis
  • ➤ Hematogenous spread from distant tubercular focus
  • ➤ Contagious spread from infected adjacent foci
  • ➤ Through lymphatic channel
  • ➤ Common site of abdominal TB - Terminal ileum and cecum
  • ➤ Feco-oral route is not known to spread abdominal TB.
  • ➤ Feco-oral route is not known to spread abdominal TB.

questions.text: Following images show the sample collected from a patient complaining of perianal itching. The diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Enterobius vermicularis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enterobius vermicularis is associated with perianal itching and produces characteristic D-shaped eggs.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As a part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was done. What is the principle of this test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Paul-Bunnell test is based on the detection of heterophile antibodies, which agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, and is used in the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: Human herpesvirus 8 is associated with all except? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Adult T-cell leukemia

questions.text: All of the following can be seen intracellularly in hepatocytes except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Babesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obligate intracellular parasites-
  • ➤ Trypanosoma cruzi Leishmania spp. Plasmodium spp. Babesia spp. -> RBC Toxoplasma gondii Microsporidia
  • ➤ Trypanosoma cruzi
  • ➤ Leishmania spp.
  • ➤ Plasmodium spp.
  • ➤ Babesia spp. -> RBC
  • ➤ Toxoplasma gondii
  • ➤ Microsporidia

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy complains of cough and throat pain. On examination of the oral cavity, a white pseudomembrane was visualized. A swab was taken from it and stained as given in the image below. What is the procedure for the following staining? (INICET NOV 2021) Albert's stain- I Acid alcohol Gram's iodine Safranin Methylene blue Crystal violet Carbol fuschin Acetone
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6, 3, 8, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct Gram staining procedure for identifying Corynebacterium diphtheriae includes the steps of applying crystal violet, adding Gram's iodine, decolorizing with acetone, and counterstaining with safranin.

questions.text: A blood spill in the operation theatre must be cleaned with? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chlorine compound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For cleaning a blood spill in the operation theatre, sodium hypochlorite, a chlorine compound, is the best disinfectant due to its effectiveness in inactivating a wide range of pathogens and its suitability for such critical environments.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms cause multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Echinococcus multilocularis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Echinococcus multilocularis causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver, leading to a serious condition known as alveolar echinococcosis. The prognosis is poor without treatment, emphasizing the importance of early detection and appropriate therapy.

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zika Virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Zika virus is known for causing microcephaly through transplacental transmission by infecting and damaging neural progenitor cells in the developing fetal brain.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is primarily associated with an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, emphasizing the importance of avoiding consumption of undercooked freshwater fish in endemic areas to prevent this parasitic infection.
  • ➤ List of Oncogenic Microbe:
  • ➤ List of Oncogenic Microbe:

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti Hbc Ab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which component of the HIV genome is necessary for the virus to enter the host cell membrane? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GP120

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GP120, a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope, is necessary for binding to CD4 receptors on host cells, facilitating viral entry.

questions.text: Which cell is involved in type 4/delayed type hypersensitivity? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Zonula occludens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The disruption of zonula occludens (tight junctions) by cholera toxin is responsible for the increased permeability of intestinal epithelial cells, leading to the characteristic watery diarrhea seen in cholera.

questions.text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago comes with complaints of diarrhea for the last 9 days. The stool sample was subject to Kinyoun stain revealing 4-6m structures shown below. Which of the following is true about the organism? ( INICET MAY 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common organism implicated worldwide

options.label: C
options.text: Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool

options.label: D
options.text: It is an obligate intracellular organism

questions.correct_answer: C. Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cryptosporidium oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool, and the infection can cause severe diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts are identifiable by their acid-fast property in modified Ziehl-Neelsen stains.
  • ➤ Cryptosporidium oocysts
  • ➤ Comparative features of coccidian parasites:
  • ➤ Comparative features of coccidian parasites:

questions.text: An individual went to the US and developed an infection. LPCB mount showed the following. Identify the cause. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Histoplasma capsulatum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histoplasma capsulatum is identified by its distinctive tuberculate macroconidia on LPCB mounts, which is a key feature to recognize this dimorphic fungus, especially in infections contracted in the United States.

questions.text: A 32-year-old laborer working at a construction site presented with fever and hemoptysis. The sputum sample collected for examination showed the following. The smear will be stained by which of the following sequences? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Methylene blue - malachite green - acetic acid-water

questions.correct_answer: D. Carbol fuschin - acid-alcohol - methylene blue
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Carbol fuschin - acid-alcohol - methylene blue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Ziehl-Neelsen staining method, involving carbol fuschin, acid-alcohol, and methylene blue, is used to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis in clinical samples. This technique highlights acid-fast bacilli, which retain the red color of carbol fuschin even after decolorization with acid-alcohol.
